required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Gastrointestinal Myoelectric Activity Protocol, the G-Tech EEnG Protocol
clinical_study.official_title: A Feasibility Study For Monitoring And Recording Gastrointestinal Myoelectric Activity In Subjects With Suspected Or Diagnosed Irritable Bowel Syndrome (Lbs) And Reports Of GI Pain And Asymptomatic Subjects Without Lbs And GI Pain

brief_summary.textblock: A feasibility study for monitoring and recording gastrointestinal (GI) myoelectric activity in subjects with suspected or diagnosed irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and reports of GI pain and asymptomatic subjects without IBS and GI pain.

detailed_description.textblock: This single-arm, non-randomized feasibility study has been designed to transcutaneously detect and monitor myoelectric intestinal signals temporally associated with the symptoms of patients who report pain and have suspected or diagnosed IBS, and in controls [subjects without suspected IBS or diagnosis of IBS and prior and/or current complaints of pain].

primary_outcome.measure: Device Success defined as the ability to record myoelectric signals in study subjects.

study_pop.textblock: Irritable bowel syndrome, functional bowel disorder.

overall_official.affiliation: G-Tech Chief Medical Officer and Medical Monitor

link.description: Description of functional GI disorders, and detailed description of myoelectric science.

reference.citation: Anand Navalgund, PhD, Steve Axelrod, PhD, George Triadafilopoulos, MD2Feasibility of measuring the contractile electrical complex over 72 hours in a healthy human subject using a wearable, wireless electrode patch. Abstract submitted to AGA IBS Conference 2015.
